entry.title: Goal & Development plan dates
entry.content:
Hi

We have a few different groups using goal plans at our organization. Some have a different performance year than others. Before with the legacy goal plan all of the groups could use the same goal plan and set dates from their goals without it matching the template goal plan dates. With the new goal plan that doesn't seem to be possible anymore.

The only solution I could get to work is is duplicating goal plans with the only different being the goal plan start and end dates. Are there any other solutions to consider? Can you set a default date for your template that is different than the start date in the template configuration?

entry.title: Re: What's the best way to see material stock and history...
entry.content: Ok, maybe Material Stock at Posting Date (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/4b7d68579552346ae10000000a4450e5.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US) or you may use that one plus some other to create your own CDS View. It is meant to answer the question "What was my total stock on a specified date?". As you are exporting the data, I would recommend one of the Extraction views if possible - often they would support CDC (Change Data Capture) or Delta requests, but your middleware needs to support that functionality (like BW) - there are several blogs here about extracting data via CDS View in the community. thank you, Jerry

entry.title: SAP Platform and Data Summit 2025: Unlock the Future of Innovation | Register Now
entry.content:
SAP Platform and Data Summit 2025: Unlock the Future of Innovation with SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Business Data Cloud | Register Now

Hello, SAP Community!

My name is Joanne Koh-Stewart, and I'm Director of Product Marketing for SAP Business Technology Platform. As we navigate an era where enterprise data management isn't just an asset—it's the foundation of every strategic decision—business leaders face an unprecedented challenge: How do you transform mountains of information into meaningful competitive advantage?

According to recent IDC research, organizations that successfully harness the power of SAP Business Technology Platform with business applications reported achieving annual benefits worth $13.88 million per organization on average. Yet, many businesses find themselves drowning in data complexity, struggling to connect the dots between various business applications, processes, and other IT investments for tangible business outcomes.

That's precisely why I'm thrilled to invite you to the SAP Platform and Data Summit 2025—an exclusive gathering designed for pioneering business leaders and IT experts ready to unlock the transformative power of intelligent data strategies with SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Business Data Cloud.

 

The Reality Check: Where Most Organizations Stand Today

Picture this scenario that's playing out in boardrooms across industries. Your organization has invested millions in digital transformation initiatives. You've implemented many applications required for your business, collected vast amounts of data, and are now hopefully looking into utilizing various AI tools. Yet when you want to optimize business processes, increase sales, engage customers, and elevate employee experience, you’re lost on where to start.

Sound familiar? The challenge isn't technology—it's the strategic alignment of SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Business Data Cloud with real business objectives. You're sitting on a goldmine of data, but the path to extracting value feels fragmented across different systems, departments, and decision-making processes.

The key lies in creating an intelligent, unified ecosystem where your SAP and non-SAP data, applications, and AI capabilities work in harmony. SAP BTP, coupled with SAP BDC and SAP Business AI, doesn't just solve technical challenges—it fundamentally reshapes how your organization thinks, learns, and competes in the market.

 

What Makes This Summit Different: Customer-Led Innovation

Unlike typical vendor conferences, the SAP Platform and Data Summit puts customer success stories at the center. You'll hear directly from IT decision-makers and business leaders who have navigated similar challenges you're facing today. These aren't theoretical case studies—they're battle-tested strategies with real business value.

The two-day format is intentionally designed for deep engagement. Day 1 focuses on hearing from customers and partners’ success stories, while Day 2 dives into collaborative workshops to learn and ideate. You'll leave not just with inspiration, but with concrete next steps tailored to your organization's unique digital transformation journey.

 

Four Essential Topic Tracks You'll Explore at the Summit

On Day 2, dedicated tracks are offered to address the most pressing challenges facing organizations today in a workshop setting. Each track combines strategic insights with practical implementation guidance from customers who have successfully navigated these transformations.


BTP for Clean Core
You: Your organization is managing a complex landscape of customizations that make system upgrades challenging and expensive. Every enhancement seems to create technical debt, and you're concerned about maintaining agility while preserving critical business functionality.
The Solution: Learn how SAP BTP enables you to extend SAP applications without compromising your core system integrity. Through customer success stories, you'll discover how organizations are leveraging the clean core principles to innovate rapidly while maintaining upgrade readiness and reducing long-term maintenance costs.

BUILD-ing AI Applications & Extensions
You: Your business needs and processes aren't always met by standard applications, but custom development is time-consuming and resource-intensive. Meanwhile, your development teams are under pressure to deliver solutions faster while maintaining quality, security, and scalability.
The Solution: Explore how SAP Build empowers both professional developers and business users to create applications and extensions rapidly. See real examples of organizations using low-code development to bridge capability gaps, automate processes, and create tailored user experiences that drive business value.

AI & Joule
You: Despite the industry's significant importance and heavy investment in AI initiatives, your organizations struggle to move beyond pilot projects to enterprise-scale implementations that deliver measurable business impact.
The Solution: Discover how SAP Business AI and Joule are revolutionizing business processes across industries. Through customer presentations, you'll witness how AI is being utilized to improve business workflows, enhance decision-making, automate complex tasks, and provide intelligent insights that drive strategic outcomes.

Business Data Cloud
You: Your organization has access to vast amounts of data from different systems, but each source speaks a different "language." Without a unified semantic model, your data remains fragmented and difficult to interpret, limiting your ability to leverage advanced analytics and planning capabilities that could transform your business performance.
The Solution: Learn how SAP Business Data Cloud harmonizes heterogeneous data into a coherent, business-ready semantic model with SAP Datasphere. Explore customer examples of organizations that have transformed disconnected data into actionable insights, enabling sophisticated analytics, predictive planning, and strategic decision-making across the enterprise with SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Register Now: Space is Limited (and FREE!)

The Summit isn't just about learning new technologies—it's about positioning your organization to lead in the data-driven economy that's already here.

🌉Register for San Francisco →| September 11–12, 2025
Customer Presenters: AMD, Siemens Healthineers, Clorox, and more
Celebrity Speaker: Andre Iguodala

🏙️Register for NYC →| September 16–17, 2025
Celebrity Speaker: Bernie Williams, former NY Yankee and 4x World Series champion
Customer Presenters: Moderna, Johnson & Johnson, Conair, and others

🏢Register for Chicago → | September 23–24, 2025
Celebrity Speaker: Former Chicago Bear Matt Forte
Customer Presenters: Southern California Edison, Endress+Hauser, Rust-Oleum, and others

🍁Register for Toronto → | October 16–17, 2025
Celebrity Speaker: NHL celebrity speaker to be announced soon
Customer Presenters: Metrie and others

🍑Register for Atlanta → | October 22–23, 2025
Celebrity Speaker: Celebrity speaker to be announced soon
Customer Presenters: Colgate, Lucid Motors, Gerdau, and more

Whether you're at the beginning of your SAP journey or looking to maximize existing investments, this Summit will provide the strategic clarity, practical insights, and professional connections to accelerate your transformation.

Register now and join the exclusive community of leaders who are turning data complexity into competitive simplicity.

 

Let's Connect

I'll be attending the Summit in Chicago this year, and I look forward to connecting with fellow transformation leaders! Come prepared with your toughest platform and data challenges—this is your opportunity to collaborate with peers who are solving similar problems and SAP experts who can provide immediate guidance.

Now let's hear from you:

  • What's your biggest obstacle in scaling your platform and data initiatives?
  • How are you currently measuring the ROI of your SAP investments?
  • What would success look like if you could unlock the full potential of your enterprise data?

Share your thoughts in the comments, and let's start the conversation before we meet in person!

entry.title: Re: RSH - Inable de change the navigation link of the wor...
entry.content:
Hi @MarkusHH 

I see the screenshot; thanks for sharing it. It shows a Lab Preview of the Operational Maintenance Orders app, where you can now configure additional links, for example, Change Maintenance Order, Create Maintenance Order, and Actual Cost Analysis via the Define Link List dialogue.

The comment in your screenshot essentially confirms:

  • In the S/4HANA 2025 release, SAP will enable customers to configure these additional links directly, rather than being restricted to the predefined list.
  • The More Links button opens the Define Link List popup, where you can select or deselect available navigation options.
  • This offers flexibility for end users, as they can customise the quick navigation links to the maintenance order they are working on.

The planned enhancement is that, starting with S/4HANA 2025, you will be able to customise the contextual navigation links available for Maintenance Orders.

Here are relevant SAP references regarding customised links and navigation within Maintenance Order apps in SAP S/4HANA

SAP Help Portal: Configure Link List for Fiori Apps
Learn how to customise your navigation links in Fiori apps to make them more personal and easier to use. This includes setting up link lists that connect to related apps, helping you find what you need quickly and effortlessly, and facilitating transactions.

SAP Fiori Apps Library – Manage Maintenance Orders
Official overview and details of the Maintenance Order app and its features, including upcoming enhancements for link customisation.

SAP S/4HANA 2025 Roadmap and Release Information
Details about new features coming in S/4HANA 2025, including improvements to link list configurability.

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Joule does not execute transactional capacity.
entry.content:
Hi @GuilhermeBaptista ,

thanks for the information and sorry for late reply.

Are you using Joule assistant from your BTP Workzone or from the S/4 Launchpad? Are both ways having the same issue that information & transaction capabilities don't work?
Per your discription, my gut feeling is below:


case 1 that information capability works but transaction capability suddenly stops working: Most possible root cause would be 1) the access/role missing issue, as transaction capability will need the end user to have the corresponding roles of the applications which could be trigger by Joule. 2) content exposure changed in your S/4 system so that some applications cannot be accessed by Joule. -- you may click the Report link to see the number of roles, apps, groups, catalogs, spaces, pages, and URL templates that are included in the content provider.

case 2 that both capabilities stop working suddenly, if this is the case, could you please go to your Joule subscription and check if it is still active 

If the joule is down, please raise a ticket to the product team:

entry.title: Transformação de Negócios com SAP Signavio e LeanIX
entry.content:
A transformação empresarial é uma constante para a organização moderna. Você precisa ser capaz de pivotar, adaptar e alavancar, não importa como as necessidades do cliente flutuem. E para fazer isso, você precisa adaptar seus processos de negócios e arquitetura de tecnologia para dar suporte a você em quaisquer esforços que precise empreender para crescer e prosperar. No entanto, é muito mais fácil falar do que fazer, pois a transformação está longe de ser algo simples.

Mesmo que você adote a complexa tarefa de adaptar sua organização para dar a ela a melhor chance de competir no mercado, você não pode simplesmente parar de  ganhar dinheiro. Pois não apenas seus acionistas ficarão insatisfeitos, mas você não será capaz de financiar sua transformação sem os recursos necessários.

Como você adapta seu negócio às necessidades do mercado sem interromper suas operações em andamento? Preparamos uma seleção de ferramentas e orientações que vão capacitar a evoluir seu negócio sem deixar de atender as necessidades do mercado.

Transformação empresarial é uma nova maneira de pensar sobre um problema antigo. O que antes chamávamos de "transformação digital" agora se expandiu para incluir qualquer tipo de mudança de impacto geral na sua organização.

Não precisamos explicar o quão turbulento o mundo se tornou cada vez mais ou como os negócios que prosperam são aqueles que se adaptam às mudanças conforme elas surgem.

Lembre-se:

 

  • A Nintendo já foi uma empresa de cartas de baralho
  • A Amazon costumava vender apenas livros
  • A Netflix ofereceu aluguel de DVD

Quando a era digital começou, todos nós inicialmente pensamos que uma única transformação digital para se adaptar à nuvem, ao trabalho remoto e ao e-commerce seria suficiente. Claro, agora percebemos que a tecnologia continuará a evoluir e precisamos evoluir com ela, mas a tecnologia não é o único ponto nessa equação.

 

Arquitetura Empresarial com SAP LeanIX

De eventos sem precedentes a problemas de cadeia de suprimentos em todo o mundo, a empresa precisa estar constantemente pronta para se adaptar às necessidades em mudança do mercado. Longe de uma transformação digital única, a necessidade de mudança organizacional se tornou uma pressão constante.

A única maneira de lidar com essa pressão é fazer da mudança um processo de negócios constante. Ao construir agilidade no próprio tecido da sua organização, você pode pivotar e adaptar seu modelo de negócios a qualquer coisa que aconteça no futuro.

Transformação e agilidade são o seu negócio agora e vão muito além de apenas atualizar para o digital. É isso que queremos dizer quando falamos sobre transformação empresarial.

No entanto, o problema com a pressão constante para transformar seu negócio é que seu negócio não pode parar enquanto você se transforma. Você não pode simplesmente pausar todas as suas operações enquanto adapta seu modelo de negócio às necessidades atuais do mercado e as necessidades do mercado nunca param de mudar.

Saltando de um trem em movimento...

A transformação empresarial pode parecer como a ação de pular de um vagão de trem enquanto ele ainda está em movimento, apenas para ele seguir em frente sem você. Suas operações de geração de dinheiro podem não ser reduzidas enquanto você transforma seu negócio para uma nova maneira de trabalhar.

Por exemplo, digamos que você precisa atualizar sua plataforma de gerenciamento de relacionamento com o cliente (CRM) para uma versão baseada em nuvem. Você deixa todos os seus processos na ferramenta antiga primeiro ou assume o trabalho complexo de migrar tudo para a nova solução?

Isso deixa você com de três opções desagradáveis:

 

  1. Cancele suas operações em andamento e perca receita até mudar para seu novo sistema
  2. Conclua todos os seus processos atuais e deixe seu pipeline esvaziar antes de lançar seu novo sistema
  3. Execute dois sistemas simultâneos ao mesmo tempo e lide com a complexidade adicional

 

As duas primeiras opções prejudicarão sua receita, enquanto a terceira aumentará seus custos. Seja qual for a sua escolha, o problema é mais do que apenas operacional e terá um impacto em seu resultado.

Para evitar perder lucros, o phase out do seu antigo sistema precisaria ser totalmente tranquilo para sua equipe e seus clientes. Sem mencionar que a integração do seu novo sistema precisaria não apenas ser igualmente tranquila, mas o valor precisaria ser imediatamente claro.

...e pulando de volta para outro

A transformação empresarial requer a saída perfeita de seus clientes e funcionários de suas antigas formas de trabalho, ao mesmo tempo em que os integra à sua nova estrutura operacional. Para manter nossa metáfora, isso vai além de pular de um trem em movimento e se torna mais parecido com saltar de um trem em movimento para outro indo na direção oposta, tente imaginar o quão complexo é isso!

Somada à mesma complexidade de transição de suas operações para sua nova maneira de fazer negócios está a necessidade de gerenciamento de mudanças. Você tem que explicar aos seus usuários, tanto funcionários quanto clientes, como a mudança os beneficiará ou a mudança é simplesmente uma inconveniência, e quando a mudança se torna constante, essa inconveniência pode se tornar intolerável.

Ao minimizar o esforço necessário para que seus usuários façam a transição para seus novos processos e garantir que você os tenha vendido sobre o valor da transição, você pode obter a adesão das partes interessadas para a mudança em todos os níveis. Se você puder repetir esse processo para cada transformação, poderá construir uma cultura de transformação contínua que capacitará sua organização a prosperar.

Para fazer isso, no entanto, você precisa saber precisamente qual valor seu novo processo terá para seus verdadeiros stakeholders. Você precisa entender as deficiências do seu antigo sistema, os pontos problemáticos do usuário e como a nova maneira de fazer as coisas superará os problemas.

O sucesso da transformação requer uma compreensão abrangente dos seus estados atuais e objetivos e de como seus usuários interagem com eles. Obter essa supervisão do seu cenário de TI e visão futura requer monitoramento e análise abrangentes, que você só pode obter com o conjunto de ferramentas certo.

Transformação empresarial em movimento

A transformação empresarial não é um processo único e pronto, e não é algo que você pode parar e fazer no seu tempo. O crescimento e a evolução contínuos do seu negócio exigem o gerenciamento de duas máquinas complexas cheias de peças móveis e a sincronização perfeita delas.

Seus estados, atual e alvo, não permanecem estáveis enquanto você muda seu negócio de um para o outro. Seu estado atual continuará a mudar, enquanto seu plano para o futuro também precisará se adaptar e evoluir, tornando ainda mais difícil planejar sua transição.

Você não pode fazer isso de olhos vendados, pois precisa monitorar constantemente cada aspecto do seu processo legado e o desenvolvimento de suas novas operações. Isso é mais do que a análise manual pode lidar, e você precisa de automações complexas projetadas e construídas para a transformação dos negócios a fim de garantir o sucesso.

Ao mapear todos os seus recursos e processos de negócios por meio de pesquisas automatizadas e pesquisas de usuários, você pode criar uma imagem completa da sua arquitetura existente e dos aplicativos de software e componentes de TI que os suportam. Usando um ambiente de design sandbox avançado, você pode então construir uma visão para seus novos processos de negócios e cenário de TI, e mapear um caminho para chegar lá.

Com um conjunto de ferramentas avançado para manter todos esses dados em um só lugar, você pode acompanhar conforme seus estados atuais e de destino mudam e mudam. Você também pode adaptar seu plano para mudança conforme você continua a avançar.

Sem essas capacidades, sua organização não será capaz de se adaptar a um mundo em rápida evolução e você corre o risco de ficar para trás de seus concorrentes. É por isso que reunimos o conjunto de ferramentas perfeito para habilitar suas transformações de negócios agora e no futuro.

SAP LeanIX e Signavio para transformação empresarial

A transformação empresarial requer supervisão detalhada e dinâmica dos processos, aplicativos de software e comportamento do usuário da sua organização. Para ajudar você a obter essa clareza sobre o cenário do seu negócio, criamos um triunvirato de ferramentas para você usar para impulsionar a transformação contínua.

Primeiro, o SAP Signavio mapeará seus processos de negócios, destacará pontos problemáticos e dará suporte a você no design de sua nova arquitetura de processos. Para impulsionar a transformação, o WalkMe guiará seu pessoal pelos seus novos processos passo a passo e fornecerá informações abrangentes sobre o comportamento deles.

Por fim, o SAP LeanIX rastreará sua tecnologia com um mapa abrangente e relatórios sobre seus aplicativos de software e componentes de TI. Isso o capacitará com a inteligência necessária para fazer a transição para uma nova tecnologia sem interromper suas operações em andamento.

E se você quer saber mais como as soluções da SAP, LeanIX e Signavio, vão te apoiar na transformação de negócios, entre em contato!!

entry.title: Re: edocument hungary - Validation Warning from NAV /SAP...
entry.content:
Hello @SebastianB 

Thank you for your feedback and for highlighting your concern.

The solution described here helps resolve a common issue in Hungary’s e-Invoicing system, where a 1 HUF rounding difference pops up between the line-level rounding in SAP and the overall validation needed by the local NAV system.

This minor discrepancy can sometimes lead to invoice validation issues and rejection by the Hungarian tax authority, but resolving it can make the process smoother.

To resolve this, SAP recommends the following.

Verifying the rounding discrepancy by comparing the payload amounts in the eDocument Cockpit.

Make sure the correct rounding configuration is maintained in the local settings, line-level rounding set as commercial

Implementing the country-specific Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) enhancement via the Business Add-In (BAdI) for Hungary e-Invoice mapping. This BAdI allows you to adjust the payload summary amounts so they precisely match the rounded totals of individual line items.

This ABAP code snippet illustrates the process of summing rounded line net amounts for each VAT rate and updating the total values in the outbound payload accordingly.

This method follows official SAP guidelines and SAP Notes, like SAP KBA 3557761, to ensure compliance with Hungary’s regulations and avoid NAV validation errors.

I understand that AI-generated content can sometimes seem generic, but in this case, the solution aligns with the practical steps advised by SAP for this particular issue.

SAP Note 3557761 – Hungary invoice failed with NAV errors (rounding discrepancy)
This SAP note explains the rounding issue, provides the regulatory context, and confirms the use of BAdI to address payload mismatches.

Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) in SAP Help Portal
Overview of DRC capabilities and country-specific enhancements, including Hungary e-invoicing processing.
Overview of the Custom Logic app and instructions for implementing country-specific mapping to modify payload fields prior to sending documents.

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: ST-PI Version Compatibility Between SAP Solution Manager and Managed Systems
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I’m looking for clarification regarding the version alignment of the ST-PI (SAP Solution Tools Plug-In) component between SAP Solution Manager and managed systems.

From what I understand, SAP recommends that ST-PI and ST-A/PI be updated across all managed systems to ensure compatibility with Solution Manager. However, it’s not entirely clear whether a managed system can run a newer version of ST-PI than the one installed on Solution Manager.

Specifically:

Is it technically supported for a managed system to have ST-PI 740 SP31, while Solution Manager is still on ST-PI 740 SP28?
Could this cause issues with services like SDCCN, EarlyWatch Alert, or Maintenance Planner?
Is there an official SAP note or documentation that defines this compatibility rule?
Any insights or references from your experience would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance!

Silvio

entry.title: CPU/Memory utilization monitoring and Workload class
entry.content:
Introduction

This document explains how to monitor resource usage in an SAP HANA system, focusing specifically on CPU utilization. Regular monitoring ensures your system runs efficiently, maintains high performance, and uses resources wisely helping to avoid slowdowns and unnecessary costs.

Monitoring CPU Usage in SAP HANA Cloud

SAP HANA Cloud offers multiple tools for monitoring system performance. One of the most accessible and useful is SAP HANA Cloud Central. Follow the steps below to monitor CPU usage effectively:

 

Step 1: Open SAP HANA Cockpit

  • Go to SAP HANA Cloud Central.

  • Right-click on your HANA instance and select "Open SAP HANA Cockpit."

    Step 2: Navigate to CPU Usage

    • In the Cockpit, open the Performance Monitor.

    •  

    • Click on CPU Usage to view current and historical CPU activity.

      Step 3: Analyze the Data

      • Review CPU usage trends over time to identify patterns.

      • Pay close attention to spikes in usage to pinpoint potential performance issues.

        Additional Tools for Monitoring Performance

        Beyond CPU usage, the Performance Monitor provides visibility into other key resources and activities that impact system performance:

        • Expensive Statements: SQL queries that consume high levels of resources. These should be analyzed and optimized first.

        • Running Statements: Shows currently running SQL statements and their resource usage.

        • Alerts: System-generated warnings about unusual activity or performance issues.

        • Background Jobs: Scheduled processes that may impact CPU and memory usage.

          By identifying expensive statements, you can see exactly which queries are causing heavy load, when they ran, and what SQL code was executed. This information is crucial for performance tuning.

          After identifying these queries, you can optimize them—either by improving the SQL logic or by adjusting execution times—so that not all resource-heavy tasks run at the same time. This ensures resources are available for other important or ad hoc operations.

          Managing Resource Consumption with Workload Classes

          To prevent system overloads, one effective strategy is to use Workload Classes. These allow you to set limits on resource usage, such as CPU or memory, ensuring that no user or query consumes more than its fair share.

          What is a Workload Class?

          A workload class defines specific rules for resource usage. When applied, it helps:

          • Prevent overutilization of system resources,

          • Maintain system stability and performance,

          • Allocate resources more fairly across users and tasks.

            Creating a Workload Class

            You can create a workload class either through SAP HANA Cockpit or by using an SQL statement. Once created, it must be assigned to a user to take effect.

            Example 1: Using SQL

             

             
            CREATE WORKLOAD CLASS "SHIGI" SET 'ADMISSION CONTROL REJECT CONTROL REJECT CPU THRESHLD' = '45';

             

             
            Example 2: More Detailed Workload Class

             

             
            CREATE WORKLOAD CLASS MyWorkloadClass STATEMENT MEMORY LIMIT 1 GB STATEMENT THREAD LIMIT 5 STATEMENT QUEUE TIMEOUT 60 SECONDS PRIORITY MEDIUM;
             

            How It Works

            Once a workload class is assigned to a user:

            • Any SQL statement that exceeds the defined limits (CPU, memory, threads, etc.) will be automatically rejected.

            • This ensures critical system resources remain available and protects the system from crashing due to overload.

              Conclusion

              Monitoring and managing resource usage in SAP HANA Cloud is essential for maintaining performance and stability. By regularly checking CPU and memory consumption, identifying expensive queries, and using workload classes, you can keep your system healthy and efficient—no matter how demanding the workload.

entry.title: Re: CSV Download in RAP via SEGW
entry.content:
Respectfully, I hate being the one that gives the bad feedback.

This is the kind of blog that explains the current situation of SAP Community:

  • New member that is able to blog about anything
  • Blog title does not even make sense
  • Blog content with so many wrong concepts and bad examples
  • Missing key information to explain how to do something
  • Content generated with AI (at least the author added the ridiculous GEN AI tag here to make it easier to identify it)
  • Tags totally unrelated with the blog itself
  • Blog shared on Linkedin with engagement of people how clearly did not care about reading this
  • No moderation intervention for almost a week 
  • No comments like this saying the obvious - this content should not belong in the SAP Community. It's poor. It's bad. It's wrong. Many other people gave up giving a feedback like this unfortunately.

I will not justify in detail the topics above. I will just say that there is no such thing as a "RAP application" nor a "RAP whatever created using SEGW" just like there is no Photoshop art created using Paintbrush. If the author is really open for feedback I am happy to share at least 13 big problems in this blog in private.

A message to you reading this comment who might want to publish some content at the SAP Community:

  1. Read the SAP Community Rules of Engagement and use Help - SAP Community whenever needed
  2. Study before publishing a technical blog
  3. Research before starting to write it so you can find existing content
  4. Research before starting to write it so you can find if your content is relevant
  5. Research before starting to write it so you know if you are adding something to the discussion
  6. If your blog is about excel, csv, file export and you found nothing similar to the content you are willing to write, go back to step 2
  7. Review it
  8. Review it again
  9. Ask someone who knows more than you to review it BEFORE publishing it
  10. If you want to publish on the same day as you start to write it, go back to step 1
  11. Correct it based on reviews
  12. If you do all that you can go on Linkedin and spread the news that you created a blog. 

If anyone does this - regardless if you are a fresher or a pro - your content will rock and be very useful for someone today or in the future even without promoting it. And it's not because you have failed those steps before that you cannot do it in the next try. 

 

 

Finally, consider having your private blog with any content that you want, created as you want, reviewed as you want. We are in a platform that is notifying thousand of expert people that will know this content if bad and everyone will see that you created it. Is it really worth it?

Again, I hate being the bad cop. I could just ignore this blog. I could give the feedback in private but my message would reach only 1 person. I do not represent the SAP Community. Maybe they disagree with me but I am sure I am representing some people in this comment.

entry.title: The Complete Joule Studio Resource Hub: Everything You Need to Get Started
entry.content:
Access Joule Studio from the SAP Build Lobby.

 

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, is a low-code/no-code environment designed for creating, deploying, and managing custom Joule agents and skills. These agents and skills, which are deeply grounded in business data, allow developers to optimize rule-based and dynamic workflows and drive precise business outcomes. Joule Studio offers an open and extensible framework to infuse agentic intelligence into business workflows that span across SAP and non-SAP systems.  

Since July, Joule Studio is generally available (GA) with the skill builder capability. This blog is your practical guide that compiles all the resources you need to understand the product and get started on building agentic AI in a structured way.   

Here’s a recommended step-by-step approach: 

  • Start with overview resources such as announcements and short videos to gain conceptual clarity 
  • Deepen your understanding with technical blogs and guided experiences 
  • Move to structured courses and other learning materials for hands-on experience. 
  • Try the live product 

 

Getting introduced 

Every product journey starts with a curiosity - what is the product, and why should I care? This phase is all about getting conceptual understanding about Joule Studio and its capabilities:   

  • Joule Studio Announcement Blog – Read the official announcement on what is being released and when 
  • Joule Studio Product Video – Two minutes overview of Joule Studio, showcasing its capabilities and unique value in enabling skills and agents for workflows across SAP and non-SAP systems 
  • Joule Studio: custom Joule skills GA blog - Read the GA announcement for the skill builder. Understand characteristics and step-to-step process for building a skill 
  • On-Demand Webinar – Watch the on-demand webinar to go a little deeper, understand key agentic AI use cases, and get a sneak peek at product capabilities: skill builder and agent builder with a demo  

 

Seeing Joule Studio in action 

Once you know what Joule Studio does, the next step is to see it in action. Watching real demos and guided experiences helps you visualize where it fits into everyday business tasks and what it can achieve: 

  • Guided Product Tour – Take a guided tour of Joule Studio to explore how you can build AI agents and Joule Skills with drag and drop simplicity to achieve specific business outcomes 
  • Interactive Value Journey: Skill Builder – See how to configure a Joule skill to connect SAP SuccessFactors with a third-party payroll system 
  • Interactive Value Journey: Agent Builder Vision – Design agents that plan, adapt, and act autonomously 
  • Custom Joule skill creation – demo video - Learn how to create a Joule skill to create an ID badge in a third-party system after a preliminary check in an SAP system 
  • Learning Journey: Introducing Joule Studio in SAP Build – learning course on Joule Studio and its capabilities 

 

Explore the product hands on 

 Ready to dig in? This phase is all about experiencing the product hands on. Here’s where you start experimenting, take on learning missions, and build skills at your own pace: 

  • Discovery Center Mission – Best practices for connecting systems and scaling your Joule skills 
  • Developer Tutorial: Build Your First Joule Skill – Deploy your first custom Joule skill that retrieves employee information from one system and uses that information in another system 

 

Get started  

This phase provides you essential documentation to help you set up and get started with Joule Studio: 

  • Partner spotlights - before you get started on your own use case, read about real world Agentic AI use cases and their implementation by our partners: Redwood, Pricefx, LeverX, and Sovanta  
  • How to get started blog - understand the step-to-step process: prerequisites, commercial details, and technical setup 
  • FAQ blog - answers to your frequently asked questions  
  • Technical Set up guide - technical set up needed to access Joule Studio within SAP Build 

 

Closing remarks

With this organized set of resources, you have everything you need - from understanding the product to getting fully set up. Whether you’re a beginner or advanced developer, these materials are designed to support you and answer your questions at every step. We can't wait to hear what you build with Joule Studio in SAP Build!

entry.title: Re: SAP AVC Need to update the Bom qnty based on characte...
entry.content:
Hello @ankit_1662 

What needs to be fixed,

Syntax
Use the AVC quantity assignment form (no quantity() function):
QUANTITY = ( <numeric expression>, 'UoM' )

Correct object context

If the characteristic is on the configuration/header, reference it from the BOM item procedure as shown below.
QUANTITY = ( $root.AVC_ANCH01 - 0.03, 'PC' )

If it appears on the BOM item itself.
QUANTITY = ( $self.AVC_ANCH01 - 0.03, 'PC' )
(Your screenshots show AVC_ANCH01; earlier, you typed AVC_ANCHO1—that typo alone can trigger 22902.)

Units
Pass the BOM item’s base unit (e.g., 'PC'). Using 'M' when the item/char is in pieces will error.

Characteristic type
Make sure AVC_ANCH01 is numeric with a unit and the value range is valid (your “0.500–3.495 PC” looks fine).

If you apply those, this should work
QUANTITY = ( $root.AVC_ANCH01 - 0.03, 'PC' )

If it continues to fail, please share:

  • Where the characteristic is assigned (header vs. item/class),
  • The BOM item base unit,
  • The exact procedure assignment location

With kind regards

Chuma

  • Statistical forecast details (only available for the target key figure for forecast). Right-click any cell in the row of the main forecast key figure and from the context menu, choose Open  Statistical Forecast Details.

 

See a screenshot of the side-panel here SAP Integrated Business Planning (SAP IBP) 2508 - Available Now!:



Note the button 'Explain' is due to Early Adopter program 'SAP Integrated Business Planning, AI-assisted forecast results analysis'. See also AI-assisted forecast result analysis.

Please note that I registered the system to the Early Adopter program mentioned above, namely SAP Innovation Management.

entry.title: Using SAP CPI to Perform POST Calls on SAP Datasphere OData API
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

In my current scenario, I need to perform both GET and POST operations on an OData API exposed from SAP Datasphere. Querying records works fine using OAuth 2.0 with the Authorization Code grant type.

Now, I have another use case where I need to push data from SAP CPI into Datasphere for integration purposes. While I know that data loading can be done using the JDBC adapter in CPI, I would prefer an API-based approach.

The key challenge I’m facing is around executing a POST request to insert records directly into Datasphere tables. Does Datasphere support inserting data into its tables via APIs, or is there a workaround required to achieve this?

If anyone has implemented this in a project, I would really appreciate your insights.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Is it possible to combine both IM & WM outbound deliveries assigned to the same Freight Order?
entry.content:
After testing the Freight Order creation with IM outbound deliveries and WM outbound deliveries, we have seen that the combination of a WM outbound delivery and an IM outbound delivery cannot be assigned to the same Freight Order. 

If we try to do this manually through 'Postman API' we can also only assign WM outbound deliveries or IM outbound deliveries. Never a combination of both. 

Is it possible to combine both IM & WM outbound deliveries assigned to the same Freight Order?

Thank you in advance! 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to combine both IM & WM outbound deliv...
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

This is actually the way the standard integration design between Transportation Management (TM), Inventory Management (IM) and Warehouse Management (WM/EWM) works in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition.

In the Advanced Shipping and Receiving process, you can integrate Transportation Management (TM) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with the following components located in the same SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system:

  • Inventory Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Inbound and Outbound)

    You can use a very simple warehouse where inventory management takes place solely at storage location level. This scenario supports manual and external planning.

  • Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Outbound)

    You can use Warehouse Management for a flexible, automated support for processing various goods movements and for managing stocks in your warehouse complex. If you have a large warehouse with multiple loading and several doors, you can organize your loading activities in detail, and decide which door and loading point can be used. It is possible to pick up goods from several warehouses at the same location. This scenario supports manual and external planning.

Or, you can integrate TM with the following external systems:

  • Third-Party Warehouse Management (Inbound and Outbound)

    You can use Warehouse Management with an integrated third-party warehouse management system. This scenario supports manual and external planning.

 Note

The system uses the storage location to determine the kind of warehouse process you use.

Advanced Shipping and Receiving

Advanced Shipping and Receiving is an integrated, end-to-end process that allows users to send, receive, and transport products. It supports mixed and multi-warehouse scenarios within one freight order. It helps you to coordinate the process steps, for example, from the arrival of trucks at the gate to the final goods movement in the warehouse. You can also combine outbound processes for ocean or air scenarios and use a storage location managed with Warehouse Management for the pick-up freight orders.

The process simplifies communication between the Transportation Management, Warehouse Management, Inventory Management, and Delivery Management components embedded in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Communication is simplified by using a harmonized data model, by applying the EDIFACT standard to EDI messages, and by providing dedicated apps. Information moves freely between the components and allows users to gain insights into the status of the products during the process.

Loading Points

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Warehouse Management component, if you have a warehouse with a loading point, then you must perform loading activities and set the handling execution status of the items and the warehouse loading stop to Loaded in the Load or Unload Freight Orders app. This is required to be able to set the handling execution status for the stop to Checked Out in TM. After the delivery is ready for shipping from the warehouse perspective, the system unassigns all the items that are not set to Loaded from the freight order in TM.

In both Warehouse Management and Inventory Management, if you do not have a loading point, the system automatically sets statuses and reports events that are related to the loading or unloading activities. These are derived when the truck checks out and after the warehouse has posted goods issue.

For more information, see Load or Unload Freight Orders in Warehouse Management.

More Information
  • For detailed sample processes, see Transportation Planning - Sample Outbound Process and Order-Based Transportation Consolidation - Sample Outbound Process.
  • For information about logistics integration in the cloud (such as integration of orders or deliveries), see Logistics Integration.
  • For information about Warehouse Management in the Advanced Shipping and Receiving process, see Advanced Shipping and Receiving.

  • For more information about third-party warehouse management, see Third-Party Warehouse Management.

  • For information about Delivery Management in the Advanced Shipping and Receiving process, see Integration with Transportation Management.

 

 For further information from the information provided in this post, please check: Warehouse Integration and Integrating Transportation and Warehouse Management.

entry.title: Re: Embedded Analytics S/4HANAPublic Cloud Guide?
entry.content:
Hello @Phil_P 

Thank you for your question about Embedded Analytics in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. I agree it can feel a bit confusing at first, as there are several apps that work together. Let me outline the typical flow and direct you to the most helpful references.

Key Applications and Their Functions

  •  Customer Data Browser / View Browser: Explore available released CDS views as data sources.
  •  Query Browser: Build ad-hoc queries using released or custom views.
  • Custom CDS Views: Create new data sources when standard views do not meet your needs.
  • Manage KPIs and Reports:  Define KPIs, set up tiles, and group them into cards for the Fiori Launchpad.

Typical Workflow

  1.  Find a Data Source → Use View Browser / Customer Data Browser to identify the appropriate CDS view.
  2. Model the Data → If necessary, extend it with Custom CDS Views.
  3. Create Queries → utilise Query Browser to define fields, filters, and aggregations.
  4. Define KPIs and Reports → in Manage KPIs and Reports, build KPIs and display them as tiles or cards.
  5. Surface in Launchpad → assign tiles or cards to business catalogues for end users.

Dashboards versus SAC

Within Embedded Analytics, you can set up KPI tiles, cards, and Overview Pages. For more advanced, multi-visual dashboards, SAP suggests using SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), which is seamlessly integrated with S/4HANA Cloud and complements Embedded Analytics.

SAP helpful References (GenAI Assisted content)

  • SAP Help Portal – Analytics in S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition
  • SAP Fiori Apps Library – Analytics
  • SAP Tutorial – Create a KPI and Tile in S/4HANA Cloud

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to Complete or Cancel a Staging?
entry.content:
A staging of type Customer must be completed manually, otherwise it remains in status Activation in Progress. Stagings of type SAP Central Business Configuration are completed automatically.

 Note: Only the staging process is finished. Changes are still recorded in database table/transport.
 Caution: Completing or canceling a staging is irreversible!
For further details, please refer to our SAP Help Portal Completing or Canceling a Staging

entry.title: Re: MIRO 自定义字段 F4 未生效
entry.content:
Hello @yuanhuiqiang 

Thanks for the screenshots and context. Here’s what we’ve verified and what to change.

F4 value not sticking after selection

This is a value-help binding issue (not approval or “missing save”). The value help probably returns a key whose type or length doesn’t match the custom field’s data element, causing the UI to reject it and clear the input.
Fix (Custom Fields & Logic):

  • Confirm Business Context = Supplier Invoice – Header and that the field is published to the Enter Incoming Invoice (MIRO) UI.
  • In the field’s Value Help, ensure the value help returns the key you want to store (not a long description/URL) and that its type/length ≤ the target field. Adjust the mapping if needed, then republish and retest.

Select invoice number → auto-fill invoice address and lock it”

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, header BAdIs for supplier invoices run on determination and validation when saving; they don’t offer interactive UI chaining or real-time dynamic editing in the MIRO (SAP GUI for HTML) app. You can:

  • Populate on save use Custom Logic (Supplier Invoice – Header) to copy the related value into the second custom field before save.
  • Make the second field read-only static via field properties. Note: dynamic property control depends on the app technology and OData service; GUI-for-HTML transactions like MIRO generally don’t support runtime field control from CFL.

Kind regards,
Chuma

 

GenAI Assisted Content (SAP helpful documentation References)

  • SAP Help – Custom Fields & Logic (overview, publish to apps). SAP Help Portal
  • SAP Help – Creating Custom Fields (business context, enable field usage). SAP Help Portal
  • SAP Help – Value Help for custom fields (key/description mapping, code list). SAP Help Portal
  • SAP KBA 2632727 – Value Help for Custom Fields & Logic (how to add value help). SAP Support Portal
  • SAP KBA 3612451 – Custom Fields FAQ (field properties and dynamic control depend on service/app type). SAP Support Portal
  • SAP Learning – Create Supplier Invoice – Advanced = MIRO (SAP GUI for HTML). SAP Learning

entry.title: Demystify Event vs. Data Streaming in EDA
entry.content:
Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) is becoming increasingly more-an-more mainstream choice for the Integration Architecture approach. EDA seems to be a right choice for the modern Enterprises, aiming toward Composable Business and its agility. EDA can provide “Decoupled Integration” which is the essence of the Compossible Business way of thinking (as already elaborated, in my previous article)[1].

EDA should be considered as a key capability and thus included in any Enterprise Architecture transformation and modernization initiative. Of course, it’s not only EDA, but EDA is the core enabler for the Composable Business Architecture, because EDA supports:

  • Scalability
  • Flexibility
  • Resilience
  • Data quality

Figure 1. EDA and its role EA

EDA is what?

An Event-Driven Architecture is an integration model built to publish, capture, process, and respond to events across distributed systems in (near) real time[2]. It uses events to trigger and communicate between decoupled services and it is common in modern applications, which are built with microservices[3].

Because of its nature (i.e. PUSH data), EDA is very often referred to Event Streaming or Data Streaming. In specific cases, we may also refer to IoT Streaming. While this small “mess” in the semantic and terminology is confusing, we are in fact always talking about the same – we are talking about an Event Broker which is providing Event Choreography for all connected client system – no matter if they are Source System(s) or Target System(s).

But what are we really talking about? Are we really providing Streaming of the Events or Data?

What is an Event?

In general terms, an Event is a thing that happens or takes place, usually with a particular importance. But it is just too broad definition. In the context of IT or OT, and EDA, we will consider that Event is any detectable occurrence or (significant) change in a system's state that can trigger a certain action. It is also discrete and immutable record of the change. In respect of EDA, we see that Event is basically a trigger for some Data (whether IT or IoT or IIoT etc.) to be pushed or published from the Source System toward Target System, which is subscribed to receive it. We are not really “sending” an Event, we are always sending some Notification (or Data in general). Event is just a trigger.

If we talk about Business Systems, like SAP S/4HANA or similar, Event would be creation of the new Sales Order or change of the Sales Order line items or so. This change is a trigger for some action – what action we are triggering this is different story…

  • We may send an Event Notification that new Sales Order line idem has been added, or some existing has been changed – usually in a form a very short message, in SAP S/4HANA with so called CloudEvent. Sending a Notification is sometime designated as Event Streaming. Ordinarily, client system(s) may invoke a RESTful request to pull additional data from the source.
  • We may send Data Notification for the new Sales Order – usually replicating full Data Record. Sending full Data Record is sometime also called Data Streaming, especially if we are replicating data from ERP System to i.e. some Analytical System or Data Lake (although this is in fact not a continuous stream of Data, but transmission of distinct Data Records based on the Business Event trigger). Ordinarily, we do not expect any response from the client system(s)
  • We may also send something in between, like Decision Notification where i.e. certain items in the Sales Order are not available (after ATP B check) but also sending a proposal of the replacement items – usually this is small message payload carrying only minimum necessary data for the client system to make a “decision”. Here we do expect client system to make a “decision” and usually invoke some further processing in the ERP System.

SAP S/4HANA system supports many standard OOTB (Out-Of-The-Box) CloudEvents, and those are mostly Event Notifications[4].

Figure 2. Example of the Event Notifications

What is Data?

Generally accepted definition could be that Data is a collection of facts, figures, symbols, or descriptions that represent something, often used for analysis, reasoning, or decision-making. We are often referring to Data as something “row”; while we observe an Information as something which was produced out of the "raw-data" – something which has Business “meaning”. From the perspective of EDA, in Business Systems like SAP S/4HANA or similar, Data is a Record or a Document (or a part of it) – i.e. Sales Order, or Business Partner, or Accounting Document etc.

What is Streaming?

In the context of IT or OT, by pure “unofficial” definition, Streaming is a continuous flow of Data from a Source System to a Target System, often processed in real-time as it arrives.

  • In the domain of IT, as indicated previously, Business Systems like SAP S/4HANA or similar, will not provide (usually) continuous flow of Data, but rather distinct messages containing specific i.e. Data Records or Documents. Even if we have huge number of messages, they would still be distinct messages being published as a result of some specific Business Event(s). Despite this, we are still (very often) using terms like Event Streaming or Data Streaming.
  • However, in the domain of OT (or IoT/IIoT), many machines or devices, can produce both (depending on the particular use-case): distinct Data based on specific Technical Events (i.e. monitoring alert or so); as well as continuous flow of Data (i.e. telemetry). In both cases we tend to call it IoT Streaming (or Edge Integration), although first use-case is more like “standard” Event Notification.

When we talk about IoT Streaming, we usually talk about large or very large number of small messages being sent by the Source System (or Device), i.e. based on different sensor reading or so.

Figure 3. Example of the Telemetry Stream

Main patterns in EDA – or just terminology “mess”?

Is Event Notification the same as Event Streaming, and is this the same as Data Streaming?

Yes and no – depends of the terminology one uses. Many companies and experts will continue using different terminologies – although, thinking of the exactly the same thing. Somehow, I tend to agree with the terminology associated mostly with SAP Advanced Event Mesh (i.e. Event Notifications, Data Notifications and Decision Notifications) supplemented with some IoT specific (i.e. IoT Notification/Command and IoT Streaming), where each of the "integration patterns" describes the actual integration use-case. However, as it usually happens, in daily communication we all tend to generalize (or simplify) too much – using Event/Data Streaming to describe all EDA "integration patterns" seams to be a move in this direction. 

To make things at least a bit easier, let me try to share “some” high level mapping, of terminology, often used in various SAP Advanced Event Mesh papers, to other (simplified) terminology, often used by Gartner and some other organizations:

Terminology

Triggered by

Other terminology

Event Notification

Business Event

Event Streaming

Data Notification

Business Event

Event or Data Streaming

Decision Notification

Business Event

Event Streaming

IoT Notification.
IoT Command

Technical Event

Edge Integration or
IoT Streaming 

IoT Streaming

Sensor reading or similar

Edge Integration or
IoT Streaming 

Here, the word "trigger" is more indicative. Of course, we may have other types of triggers - i.e. building custom Event Notifications based on some other type of ERP events or even based on scheduled jobs.

Final note

If you have noticed some inconsistency in this article, then you are right!

Let me now explain. If we talk about stream or continuous flow of Data, to be absolutely correct, we may even say – hey, this is not “really” Event-Driven Architecture, as there is no Event triggering anything… Technically, this is current! But EDA is about Event Broker – and modern Event Brokers are capable of handling huge volumes of messages per second (or less) so, whether we are talking of IT Business Data, or OT continuous flow of Data, we would Orchestrate it (or provide Choreography – to be more precise) using an Event Broker.

So, let us adopt – no matter whether we publish message payloads based on Events, or they are based on sensor reading; no matter if it is small, or large message; no matter if clients are Business Systems, or clients are IoT devices – if we are using an Event Broker, we will consider this to be EDA integration model.

Well, this is at least my view, and my (simplified) "understanding"... 

Acknowledgment

*) Intro photo by César Abner Martínez Aguilar on Unsplash 

**) Telemetry data/graph using Microsoft Copilot AI.

***) This article uses SAP Business Technology Platform Solution Diagrams & Icons as per SAP Terms of Use governing the use of these SAP Materials (please note, newer version of the Solution Diagrams & Icons, as well as Terms of Use, might be in place after the publication of this article).

More guidelines on Solution Diagrams & Icons can be found in this article by Bertram Ganz.

References

[1] SAP Blogs: Integration patterns for the Composable Business A... - SAP Community

[2] SAP: What is Event-Driven Architecture (EDA)? | SAP

[3] AWS: Event-Driven Architecture

[4] SAP: Events | Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

entry.title: 🔒 Evolving Security in SAP BTP – Goodbye APIAccess Plan, Hello BTP CLI
entry.content:
🔐SAP BTP Security Shift: From APIAccess Plan to BTP CLI Credentials

🙋‍ About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

🌟Introduction

SAP is continuously evolving its security and authorization capabilities on the Business Technology Platform (BTP). One major shift is the move away from the APIAccess plan for Authorization and Trust Management Service towards BTP CLI Security API Credentials.

This transition brings more centralized control, enhanced governance, and future-ready security management.

❓Why the Shift?

  • The APIAccess plan was primarily used for developers to generate OAuth credentials via the cockpit.

  • SAP has marked it obsolete, pushing customers to adopt the more powerful BTP CLI Security API credential management.

  • This aligns with SAP’s strategy of delivering CLI-first, automation-ready tooling.

💡Benefits of Using BTP CLI

✅Centralized credential management at the subaccount level
✅Fine-grained, role-based access (requires Security Administrator role)
✅Automation-friendly (ideal for CI/CD pipelines)
✅Better lifecycle management (create, rotate, revoke credentials via CLI)
✅Future-proof – new features/enhancements will come only in BTP CLI

⚖️Key Differences: APIAccess vs BTP CLI Security API Credentials

Aspect APIAccess Plan BTP CLI Security API Credentials
ScopeBound to a specific service instanceManaged at subaccount level
Access RoleTypically developer role (CF)Requires Security Administrator role
ManagementCreated via cockpit UIManaged via BTP CLI commands
AutomationLimitedFully automation-ready (CI/CD, scripts)
Future SupportDeprecated / ObsoleteActively supported & enhanced
GovernanceMinimalStrong audit & lifecycle management

🛠Steps to Manage Security API Credentials via BTP CLI

1️⃣Login to BTP CLI

btp login --url https://cpcli.cf.eu10.hana.ondemand.com --subdomain <your-subdomain>

2️⃣Create Security API Credential

btp create security/api-credential --subaccount <subaccount-guid> --name <credential-name>

3️⃣List Security API Credentials

btp list security/api-credential --subaccount <subaccount-guid>

4️⃣Get Details of a Credential

btp get security/api-credential --subaccount <subaccount-guid> --name <credential-name>

5️⃣Delete Security API Credential

btp delete security/api-credential --subaccount <subaccount-guid> --name <credential-name>

📸Real-Life Example (POC)

Login to BTP CLI

btp login --sso

It will open browser to enter userid and password. Once authenticated successfully in browser user will be logged in the BTPCLI

User should have security admin privileges to perform this task using BTPCLI as highlighted below:

Command to create BTP Security api credentials

btp create security/api-credential --name APIConnectivitySecurityCred

Command to list the security api credentials

btp list security/api-credential

Command to get the security api credentials:

 btp get security/api-credential APIConnectivitySecurityCred

Command to delete the security api credentials:

btp delete security/api-credential APIConnectivitySecurityCred

🔄Migration Guidance: Moving from APIAccess Plan to BTP CLI Security API Credentials

👉Why migrate?

  • ✅APIAccess plan is deprecated/obsolete.

  • ✅BTP CLI provides a centralized, secure, and role-based way to manage credentials.

  • ✅Future enhancements will be delivered only for the BTP CLI approach.

👉Suggested migration approach:

  1. Identify all applications, integrations, or scripts currently using credentials generated via APIAccess plan.

  2. Recreate credentials using BTP CLI with the required Security Administrator role at the subaccount level.

  3. Update configurations (destination services, API clients, pipelines, etc.) to consume the new credentials.

  4. Decommission old credentials to avoid accidental usage.

📌Tip: Run this migration in a test subaccount first to validate all dependencies before rolling out in production.

🙋‍♂️ FAQs

Q1: Do I still need the Space Developer role for managing credentials?
👉No. Managing Security API Credentials requires the Security Administrator role at subaccount level, not CF space roles.

Q2: What happens if I continue using APIAccess plan?
👉APIAccess is obsolete. Existing instances may continue temporarily, but no future support or enhancements will be provided.

Q3: Can I automate credential rotation with BTP CLI?
👉Yes ✅. You can script credential creation/deletion via BTP CLI and integrate into CI/CD pipelines for automated rotations.

📚References

  • SAP Help: What’s New – Authorization and Trust Management Service

  • SAP Help: Managing API Credentials for Authorization and Trust Management Service

entry.title: Re: Find Maintenance Orders
entry.content:
Hello @Matthew_Hartung 

Here is a brief definition of the three flags,

  • Outstanding Purchasing: The order still has external procurement ongoing (PR/PO item not fully received/closed; remaining qty > 0).
  • Outstanding Reservations: A stock material reservation on the order has an open withdrawal quantity that is required > issued; not deleted.
  • Outstanding Services: A service procurement line for a lean service PO isn’t fully serviced or accepted yet, and there is no fully posted or accepted service entry; remaining quantity is greater than zero.

Note below highlights 

  • These are order-level indicators: if any line remains open, the order is marked as Yes.
  • TECO generally reduces open PRs and reservations; if TECO occurs before GI/SES posting, the flag can remain 'Yes' until postings are completed.

Let me know if it helps

Best regards,
Chuma

 

 

SAP helpful References (GenAI Assisted Content)

  • SAP Help Portal – Find Maintenance Orders (F2175). SAP Help PortalSAP Fiori Apps Library
  • SAP Learning Journey (Public Cloud EAM) notes on Technical Completion, reducing open PRs/reservations. SAP Learning+1
  • SAP Help – Manage Service Entry Sheets (Lean Services). SAP Help Portal

entry.title: How to perform a calculation based on the value of another wage type as of a specific point in time
entry.content:
We have the need to perform a calculation based on the value of another wage type as of a specific point in time.

We have a new law that states someone can receive a supplemental payment based on the point in time where they reached 30 years of service.

Background.  WT9918 is a variable wage type for Length of Service that is populated on IT2010 from an inbound interface.  We use this wage type to determine different things but in this specific case I am looking for 30 years of service.  Once employees in 4 specific employee groups have WT9918 on IT2010 I need to capture their WT/001 as of that specific point.  Then perform a calculation when they retire based on the value in /001.  For example: Employee A has WT9918=30 in April 2025.  In April 2025 his WT/001 = $45.00.  Months pass and this employee retires in November 2025.  They are eligible to receive a supplemental payment indefinitely based on the WT/001 in April 2025.  Note: their salary changed on 7/1/2025 in return changing their /001 amount but their WT9918 is now greater than 30.  I don't want the 7/1/2025  WT/001 value for this calculation or even the value of their /001 as of November 2025.  I want the WT/001 value of $45.00 because that is when their WT9918=30.  

How do I make this happen?  I know how to do it looking at current results - not on previous results that could be months or even years old.  

Thanks in advance

Aimee

entry.content:

Agradezco su ayuda si me pueden decir como se genera el /37P de donde sale este concepto

entry.title: Re: SEN Documentation templates
entry.content:
Hi Mel,

To import new documentation templates into Producer:
1. Start editing the Resources > Adaptable Resources > Documentation Style object - you must have the green editing pencil
2. Click on the Documentation Style object so that it is selected
3. Right click the object and choose Insert File
4. Locate and open your template - .dot or .dotx both work

Once you import the new template, it will be located at the bottom of the existing templates.  Watch this video if you want to learning more about importing and using your own branded documentation templates.

Regards
Shane

Hello @Paulo_Castrop 

There isn’t a public forum dedicated solely to Learning Hub. For open knowledge sharing, use SAP Community under the SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) topic. For discussions within Learning Hub, use the Learning Rooms (subscriber access).

Below are where you should engage;

  • SAP Community – EWM (public): ask questions, read blogs, and network in the EWM topic area. pages.community.sap.com
  • Learning Hub – Learning Rooms (subscribers): collaborate with instructors and learners; in Learning Hub go to Content Library → Learning Rooms → Groups to join/post. learninghub.sap.com
  • SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps (if you have Enterprise Support): the Supply Chain Management Solutions value map includes EWM enablement and a guided community. support.sap.comSAP Learning

Practical materials for EWM in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  • Warehouse Management (Public Edition) training hub page (overview and links). SAP Learning
  • Learning Hub Help Center (general guidance and support). learninghub.sap.comSAP Learning

With kind regard,
Chuma
